title: Vulnerable Road Users: Protect Everyone Sharing the Road
summary: Understand the needs of pedestrians, cyclists, horse riders, and more so you can plan safe, respectful interactions.

sections.title: Why Vulnerable Users Need Extra Care
sections.body: People outside of vehicles have less protection and may behave unpredictably. Prioritising them keeps journeys safe and aligns with the Highway Code’s hierarchy of road users.

sections.title: DVSA Essentials
items: Hierarchy of road users: those who can cause the greatest harm have the greatest responsibility to reduce danger.
Give cyclists at least 1.5 m clearance at speeds up to 30 mph and more when faster or in bad weather.
Rule 215–222: Pass horse riders slowly (max 10 mph) and with wide clearance; be prepared to stop.

sections.title: Key Vulnerable Groups
items: Pedestrians: especially children, older people, and those with reduced mobility or visibility.
Cyclists and e-scooter riders: may wobble to avoid drains or potholes.
Motorcyclists: accelerate and brake quickly—check mirrors before turning or changing lanes.
Horse riders: animals can be startled by noise or sudden movement—follow their signals.

sections.title: High-Alert Scenarios
items: Approaching zebra and parallel crossings—be ready to stop even if pedestrians have not stepped off yet.
Cyclists filtering on the left in traffic—check mirrors and blind spots before moving off or turning.
Residential streets—expect children to appear between parked cars, especially near schools.
Rural lanes—look for mud or horse droppings that indicate riders ahead.

sections.title: Safe Communication
sections.body: Use eye contact, gentle signals, and clear positioning to show your intentions. Avoid revving or using the horn unless warning of immediate danger.

checklist.label: I follow the hierarchy of road users and give priority to those most at risk.
I leave at least 1.5 m when overtaking cyclists and more at higher speeds.
I slow to 10 mph or less and pass horses calmly, ready to stop if signalled.
I check mirrors and blind spots for filtering riders before turning or moving off.

practiceTips.label: Crossing watch
practiceTips.detail: Spend ten minutes observing a busy crossing. Notice how pedestrians communicate and how drivers show they’re yielding.

practiceTips.label: Theo’s courtesy wave
practiceTips.detail: If someone lets you pass, raise a hand to thank them. Courtesy builds goodwill and keeps stress low.

practiceTips.label: Ride or walk the route
practiceTips.detail: Experience your usual driving route on foot or by bike. You’ll notice pinch points and visibility challenges to plan for when driving.

questions.prompt: What clearance should you give when overtaking cyclists at up to 30 mph?

options.label: At least 1 metre
options.explanation: DVSA guidance specifies a minimum of 1.5 m under 30 mph.

options.label: At least 1.5 metres
options.explanation: 1.5 m gives cyclists space to wobble or avoid potholes safely.

options.label: Whatever space is available without crossing the centre line
options.explanation: If you cannot leave 1.5 m, wait. Overtaking too close is unsafe and can be illegal.

options.label: Half a metre if the cyclist is wearing bright clothing
options.explanation: Visibility doesn’t reduce the clearance you must give—1.5 m is the minimum.

questions.prompt: How should you pass a horse and rider?

options.label: Use the horn to warn them and pass at normal speed
options.explanation: Loud noise may startle the horse and cause loss of control.

options.label: Slow to 10 mph or less, give plenty of room, and be prepared to stop
options.explanation: Follow the Highway Code guidance to keep the rider and horse safe.

options.label: Drive close so the horse can’t move into your lane
options.explanation: Crowding a horse is dangerous; they may kick out or panic.

options.label: Pass between the horse and the kerb to protect oncoming traffic
options.explanation: Never squeeze through—give the horse a wide berth and wait if necessary.

questions.prompt: You’re turning left at a junction and suspect a cyclist may be on your inside. What should you do?

options.label: Turn quickly before they reach you
options.explanation: Turning across a cyclist risks a collision and is a common serious fault.

options.label: Check mirrors and blind spots, signal early, and wait if the cyclist is alongside
options.explanation: Only turn when you’re sure the space is clear.

options.label: Assume they will stop and continue
options.explanation: Never assume—cyclists may be in your blind spot and have priority when ahead.

options.label: Sound your horn to warn them you’re turning
options.explanation: Using the horn can startle cyclists—wait until the turn is safe instead.

questions.prompt: Why is the hierarchy of road users important?

options.label: It tells you who has the right to break traffic laws
options.explanation: No one is allowed to break traffic laws.

options.label: It reminds drivers they carry the greatest responsibility to protect others
options.explanation: Drivers can cause more harm, so they must take extra care around vulnerable people.

options.label: It allows drivers to claim priority over pedestrians
options.explanation: The hierarchy does the opposite—pedestrians are at the top and must be protected.

options.label: It lists which roads are most important
options.explanation: The hierarchy focuses on protecting people, not ranking roads.

questions.prompt: You approach a zebra crossing where pedestrians are waiting at the kerb. What should you do?

options.label: Slow down, be prepared to stop, and allow them to cross
options.explanation: Drivers must give way once pedestrians show intent to cross at a zebra crossing.

options.label: Maintain speed if the pedestrians haven’t stepped onto the crossing
options.explanation: Failing to slow could endanger them—be ready to stop.

options.label: Flash your headlights to tell them to wait
options.explanation: Flashing headlights can confuse pedestrians; instead, slow down and stop.

options.label: Sound the horn and continue
options.explanation: The horn should not be used to demand priority over pedestrians.
